Award.AwardTitle: Hydrolysis of Cellulose and Lignocellulosic Biomass into Fermentable Sugars using Acidic Ionic Liquid Medium

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0929970
Amarasekara

The goal of this project is to develop an efficient and environmentally sound hydrolysis method useful for the production of glucose and other fermentable sugars from lignocellulosic biomass. The glucose and other fermentable sugars produced from abundant lignocellulosic biomass provide an economical path to ethanol production. This anticipated goal would be achieved by the development of a recyclable acidic ionic liquid solvent system that can easily dissolve lignocellulosic biomass and act as the hydrolysis catalyst as well. In the initial stage of the project three different types of acidic ionic liquids will be synthesized by using 1-methylimidazole, triethanolamine and pyridine as bases. These acidic ionic liquids will be tested for their ability to dissolve cellulose under thermal, microwave, and sonication conditions. The resulting cellulose-acidic ionic liquid solutions will be then diluted with water to a critical concentration and allowed to hydrolyze by the internal -SO3H group in the ionic liquid, acting as the catalyst. Glucose and its oligomers produced in the hydrolysis will be analyzed by HPLC. Furthermore, the total reducing sugars formed will be analyzed by 3,5-dinitrosalicylic acid or alkaline copper methods. In the second stage of the project acidic ionic liquids with a built-in superacid group (-CF2-SO3H) will be synthesized and then similarly tested for the dissolution and hydrolysis of cellulose to study the catalytic effect of the superacid group. In the third phase, the use of acidic/superacid ionic liquids for the dissolution and hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass (corn stover, switch grass, miscanthus grass, wood chips) to fermentable sugars will be investigated. In the fourth phase of the project optimization of reaction conditions to produce the maximum yield of fermentable sugars, recovery and recycling of these acidic ionic liquids will be studied.

The intellectual merits of the project are (a) acidic/superacid ionic liquid is the solvent and the catalyst as well, therefore no waste in acid and no separation of acid catalyst is necessary (b) single step dissolution and hydrolysis under mild temperatures and atmospheric pressure (c) superacid ionic liquid is a novel concept. Broader impacts of the project are (a) participation of minorities, as this project will be carried out at Prairie View A&M University, which is a historically black university (b) postdoctoral research associates, graduate and undergraduate students will participate in the project providing them professional development, research training and education (c) broad dissemination of knowledge about sustainable energy technologies by presentation of the results at conferences, group meetings, and publications in journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to develop an environmentally sound and industrially feasible cellulose hydrolysis method for the cellulosic-ethanol process. The plan for achieving this goal involved the development of a recyclable acidic ionic liquid solvent system that can act as the hydrolysis catalyst. We have productively completed all the primary tasks proposed in the project. In addition we have discovered that these ionic liquids can be used as cellulose depolymerization catalysts in aqueous medium as well. During the initial phase a series of acidic ionic liquids were synthesized, characterized and studied for the dissolution and hydrolysis of cellulose in ionic liquid medium.  Five different types of cellulose samples in acidic ionic liquids (1-3) were studied. All five types of cellulose samples were found to dissolve in imidazolium type ionic liquids (1a-b) within 2-5 min. at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Optical microscopy images during the dissolution of Sigmacell cellulose in 1-(1-propylsulfonic)-3-methylimidazolium chloride (1a) are shown in figure 1. These cellulose samples were found to dissolve in triethnolammonium (2) and pyridinium (3) ionic liquids when allowed to stand at room temperatue for 24 hr. Cellulose hydrolysis could be carried out in these ionic liquids after adding 2 eqv. of water per glucose unit and heating at 70 C for 0.5-1.0 h, producing 62% TRS and 14% glucose yields.

Next we studied the use of ionic liquids as catalysts in aqueous medium. In the last stages we concentrated our efforts on recovery of ionic liquid catalysts, structure activity relationships of ionic liquids, reaction mechanisms and applications on raw biomass samples. In comparison with other tasks, efficient recovery of the ionic liquid catalyst was the most challenging aspect of the project, where we had some difficulties in the development of a truly efficient technique.

Overall, we have successfully completed the project resulting 14 publications in peer reviewed journals and presenting some of the results at two conferences, including 2011 International symposium on Alcohol Fuels (ISAF XIX) held in Verona, Italy.The project delivered the targets in human resources development aspects as well. One postdoctoral research associate was supported and trained in cellulosic ethanol research for about an year, two M.S. level graduate students were partially supported from the grant. These two graduate students completed their M.S. thesis projects and graduated, they are currently employed; one as an analytical chemist in a chemical industry and the other as a high school chemistry teacher in a local public school. During the project period five undergraduates were involved in the project and some of these students were supported by grant funds during the regular semester and summers. All five undergraduates successfully completed their B.S. degrees. One entered the medical school, one to pharmacy school and another student was accepted to the dental school.
